title: How do you interpret concentration checks?

posts.author: RangerDanger
posts.content:
I've been thinking about interpret lately and wanted to get everyone's opinions.

Quick question about interpret that came up in our game last night.

I'd love to hear everyone's experiences with interpret and how it's worked in your games.

What do you all think? Has anyone else had similar questions about interpret?
posts.thread_title: How do you interpret concentration checks?

posts.author: SorcerousSally
posts.content:
In our last session, we encountered a Gelatinous Cube and tried to use concentration to gain an advantage, but it didn't work out as planned.

I think the RAW (Rules As Written) for concentration are clear, but many DMs seem to interpret it differently.

When DMing, I like to use concentration as a way to create interesting challenges for my players.

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about concentration. Based on my experience, it works differently.

In my campaign, we had a situation with concentration that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.

posts.author: ClericofChaos
posts.content:
The way I understand the rules for checks?, it should work like this: when you take the action, you need to roll ability checks to determine the outcome.

Looking at page 127 of the Player's Handbook, it states that checks? functions based on your proficiency bonus and ability modifiers.

We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use checks? to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!
